Aroma: herbs, caramel, grapefruit.
Appearance: clear amber color and thin white head.
Taste: medium herbal bitterness, weak citrus notes, caramel, semi-dry.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, bitter finish.
Overall: Decent PA, quite drinkable.

Can.Light amber body with nice white head. Aroma is fruity citruis with some pine. Taste is caramel malts wizjh pines and maybe some honey. Aftertaste is nice bitter perfectly balanced by the caramel swetness. Very nice one.

I have seen this at stores a lot and finally decided to give it a tree. Not all that impressed. Seems to lack the citrusy flavor of many APAs. Much more on the malty bitter side. Not what I was expecting. Not a bad beer, but very average.

I give this beer respect by not going for full IPA zesty profile. Malts tastes like an old English ale with a juicy bread skin and sugar background. The hop profile is biting a lot. That’s a bitter beer no doubt. Yet quite interestingly well balanced into the sweetness of malts. It’s also quite tea like with resin and herbal notes to it. Nice.

Aroma: clean and hoppy with a few malty undertones; Appearance: clear, amber pour with white head that dissipates fairly quickly; good lacing; Taste: distinctive hops but not overwhelming; Palate: very light bodied with medium bitter finish; Overall: very pleasant, lighter beer; would definitely buy again.

12 oz. can. Pours a clear copper with a creamy and persistent off-white head. Lots of lacing. This is a nice looking beer. Aroma of citrus and pine. Taste is caramel malt, subdued citrus and grapefruit notes, and plenty of piney hops bitterness. High carbonation levels. Light to medium-bodied. Rather rich for a pale ale, it’s almost approaching IPA territory. Regardless of its category, it’s wholly satisfying.

Ljus bärnsten med stort vitt skum som fäster på glaskanterna. I doften finns en dov fruktighet, örter, blommor, fruktkola (och när den blir varmare lite disktrasa). Fyllig smak med maltsötma, dov fruktighet, örter blommor, fin avslutande beska. Välbalanserad! En riktigt bra pale ale.
Beautiful deep copper color with white head. Aroma is piney, resinous. Taste is bitter, grassy, a bit of a toasty malt body, but just a bit. Dry overall. Very good!
Can to snifter. Nose is moderate in citrus, mostly grapefruit. Taste is moderate in caramel, slightly sweet, chewy. Modest hop bitterness and flavor. More like an extra pale ale and very chewy.
Pours clear clear copper. Aroma is balanced, hoppy with pine. Taste is nice and balanced hoppy but not overwhelming.
Can. Pours dark copper. Has a big bold taste light body and a big taste of a pale ale. Has a citrus taste and a nice sweet after taste. Great beer

Copper colored, bit unclear, small off white not very lasting head. Aroma is of caramel malt, tropical fruits and bit pine . Taste is medium sweet caramel malt, tropical fruits, some biscuit, citrus, moderate hoppy aroma and bitterness, dryish finish, bit bready. Medium bodied, soft carbonation, oily. 
(can, Bierhalle Deconinck, Vichte)

Tap@BrewDog, Edinburgh - orange Amber pour with white head and lacing. Sweet fruity and malty with some caramel malty backing, slight toffeeish, mandarin, citrus peel, pretty decent IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a crystal clear copper color small off white head. Aromas of citrus and woody hops with some fruit deep down in the glass. Flavor is mildly fruity, light malt and a good amount of hop bitterness. The malt has a short finish with the hops going much longer.Light to medium bodied and very soft feeling on the tongue.
From tap at Mi2 at Cardinal 15.02.16. Clear, dark orange amber. Off-white head. Aroma and taste of pale caramel, mango and citrus. Fine aftertaste.
On tap at Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours clear amber with little off-white head. Aroma of caramel, grapefruits, resin. Tastes slightly sweet, but bitterness dominates. Distinct bitter finish.

Chmiele: Northern Brewer na goryczkę, Cascade i Columbus na smak, Centennial na aromat. 


Kolor: Bursztynowy. Klarowny w pełni. 


Piana:  Kremowa, bardzo bujna, średnio oczkowa.
Piana gęsto oblepia ścianki szkła pozostawiając grube firany na krawędziach. 


Zapach : Hymmm...co tu dużo mówić - znowu się cholernie zawiodłem:( Zapach lekki i mało wyrazisty. Prawie śladowe ilości owoców tropikalnych. Cytrusów tyle co na lekarstwo. Pozostał już tylko karmel i zioła... 


Smak: Subtelnie owocowy, bez wyraźnych wskazań na jakieś konkretne owoce. Piwo ma wybitnie ziołową formę.
Goryczka wysoka z ziołową nutą w tle.
Po chwili lekka trawiastość na języku.
W smaku wyczuwalna również metaliczność. Test na skórze potwierdził.
Nie powiem, że nie jest pijalne, ale na bank partia z tą datą nie należy do najlepszych. 


Wysycenie: Bardzo wysokie. 


Podsumownie:

Powoli chyba odpuszczam sobie kupowanie amerykańskich jasnych piw. Nie ma po prostu sensu wydawanie (dość sporych) pieniędzy na nie.
Testowałem już butelki, jak i również puszki.
Aromat jest bardzo ulotny, a smak nie tak głęboki jak powinien być.
Niestety musi to być bardzo świeża warka, aby przetrwała trudy dalekiej morskiej podróży.

Browar Oskar Blues z Longmont, Colorado szczyci się produkcją piwa w puszkach.
Propaguje ich używanie jako doskonały sposób zabezpieczania piwa przed promieniami słonecznymi oraz ulenieniem.

Nawet puszka w tym przypadku nie pomogła i uczyniła z tego jakby na to nie patrzyć cenionego i bardzo znanego na świecie piwa - zwykłego przeciętniaka.
Może przyjdzie kiedyś okazja testowania innego, świeżego piwa, wtedy wrażenia będą lepsze.
Nice lacing, great copper color. Slight bite and not quite smooth, aroma is faint. Above pale ale for the value and everyday drinkability.

A great go to beer. Pours dark amber, thin head. Possibly a wee bit too carbonated. Loads of hops and bitterness, which persists. For an American pale it has a depth, sweetness and clout which almost tips it into Imperial territory. Punches above its ABV Good stuff.

This is a beautiful beer in the glass. very prominent hop profile. I would call this an IPA, but these days you might call it an American pale ale. Darker than I expect, it's a nice Amber. Good ratio of sweet bitter and alcohol. Next time I'm looking for an IPA I'll consider this one. Of course if you're drinking it from the can you might be having a different experience. Cheers!

On tap @ Dorothy 6. Pours a medium orange amber with a thin white head. Not much of an aroma. I found this to be very ordinary and plain. It was fairly smooth and somewhat crisp with a slightly bitter finish. Nothing special here, I’ll be moving on.

Can from Whole Foods Market in Mountain View, CA. Pours amber with a thick, creamy head that lingers. Aroma is bready, malty, hoppy. Taste is the same. This is really good...incredibly balanced and bready/beefy. A go-to pale ale (akin to Anchor’s Liberty Ale).
My go-to beer......great balance of malt and hops. Packs a nice finish without overwhelming you. Light enough for beach season, but also robust enough for a wintry day by the fire.

Can at The Font, Manchester. Pours a hazy amber colour with a fizzy off white head. Aroma of toasted malts, caramel, slight cereal, some grapefruit, a little mango and pine. Taste of toasted malts, caramel then big grapefruit, some orange, slight mango, resin and grassy hops. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. A dry, lingering, toasted, resinous hop bitterness in the finish. More like an IPA than a APA, big grapefruit and resinous hops balanced perfectly with toasted malts and caramel, really smooth for a 6.5 too. Highly anticipated and enjoyed it.
Can. Hazy amber with plenty of fizz and a decent, off-white, head. Citrus fruit, grassy hops, some strong cereal mlats and a dryish finish. Enjoyable.

12 oz can served in a mug (from notes).  Revisited with a very fresh (7 days old) can in July 2017.  

Pour is medium-dark amber; surprisingly dark for style, and suggesting a rich PA. Clear with a nice creamy light tan head, about 2 fingers from a rather gentle pour. 

Aroma: somewhat vague blend of hops but with a slight off-odor. 

T - Both citrus and pine notes suggest multiple hops {the brewer says "four kinds of American hops"}. Quite hoppy for a PA, yet only mild-to-moderate bitterness. Detectable malt contribution here, but balanaced towards the hops. Slight off-note in the aroma was essentially masked by the hops and malt in the taste. Flavor improved with a bit of warming from a cold pour. 

M - medium body; rather full for style. Good carbonation. 

O - Dale’s Pale Ale is easy to recommend for "no glass" situations when one needs canned beer and wants one that is hoppy.

From can, pours light amber color with a frothy beige head. Resiny aromas with a touch of sweet malt. This is a fresh, medium-hopped brew, not over the top bitter. Flavors are balanced with a dose of malt, with a pleasant, lingering, slightly piney finish. Nicely done, rapidly becoming my go-to owing to excellent local distribution.

Malty, not much hop aroma or taste. Mild bitterness. Too malty and will not buy again. Kinda like coast hopart which is also very malty. Would get at a bar if that all they had. Used to like this beer until I became a hop head. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz can on 09-Oct-2015 at Brewerkz, Stadium, Singapore. Hazy amber colour with a thick white head. Aroma of malt, caramel, pine and tropical fruits. Nice bitterness on the palate. Lots of tropical fruit, citrus, apricot and hops.
Old note. Canned. Aroma has grassy and citric hops.Unsure about looks since well.. Straight from the can! The taste is light sweet, light-moderate bitter, has biscuit, citrus, grass. Good one.

Beer 4 of the US tour. The perfect refresher for 29 degree weather in LA. Not an overly hoppy nose but great hoppy flavour coming through. The malt profile is just enough to provide some backbone but also just enough to let the hops shine. This would be a go to summer beer if I could get it back home!

Poured from a can. Copper orange hue with no haze, foamy white head that sticks nicely as I drink. Mild Carmel sweetness with citrus & pine in the flavor. Some apricot in the nose. Moderate dryness that lingers.

Can in LA. Lasting creamy white head. Big hoppy aroma, moderate bitterness, it’s an APA not an IPA but it’s close! Fresh, fruity, citrus and some grassy hops. Really nice refreshing summer beer, but the alcohol catches up on this big can. Great APA.

Poured from 12 ounce can at Southern Culture On The Skids concert at the Southgate House Revival on May 9, 2015. Medium to dark amber hue, nice citrus/hop nose, good bittersweet flavor with lots of fruit and some complexity. Could stand a little stronger hop profile but this is a very flavorful brew.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from craft beer cellar Waterbury dated from August a: light caramel, citrusy, earthy notes app: clear dark cooper white head t/p: med body with moderate long bitter finish. O: glad that I finally got a hold on this classic of the classic. Well done.
The aroma is full of fresh hops, and some sweet malt. As a pale ale, it has a slightly thin mouthfeel, but has a clean bitter hop finish

From 12oz can to tulip glass. Pour is a nice red-orange with a thick off white head. Nose is rich hops, malt, bready, pine, touch of caramel. Taste is medium bodied, bitter with sweet notes coming through. Awesome mouthfeel, almost a juicieness to it with several flavors. Awesome beer

Warning: this does not taste like most pale ales. It is more like an IPA. I guess that’s why i like it since those are my favorite category, I also love that this comes in a can: far more portable and better environmentally.
Can: Amber in color with a white head and some lacing. The aroma is pine and citrus with a lite bitterness in the taste.

Can. Pours deep amber. Nose is resiny pine, some fruitiness. Flavor is complex for a pale ale - lots of intriguing full ale flavors - a great smattering of resiny US hop flavors, bright and just a little dank - hops are assertive but blend well with the rich toasty malt background. Finishes hop forward- some pine and a pleasant bitter bite.
Very IPAey. Tasty hops profile with big flavors and lasting citrus hop aftertaste. Big beer in a small can.

Six pack of cans. Pours out a clear light golden amber. Frothy light tan head. Lemon-pine aromas and flavor. Decent malt sweetness with notes of pine, citrus, pepper and floral notes. Long bitter finish. This is really an IPA in APA clothing.
I wouldn’t expect much from a beer in a can, but wow is this an excellent offering from Oskar. Nice mellow ale flavor - good citrus with some hops on the finish.

Poured from a can. Copper with a foamy, long lasting, off-white head. Aroma is a little malty, some pine notes. Taste is sweet, malty, bready, with some bitterness in the end. Very well balanced flavor profile, great blend of malt and hop flavors. Palate is pretty smooth, some bubbles, medium feel overall. Definitely a solid and flavorful beer. Very enjoyable.
A hoppy and gentle citrus note this well balanced pale ale. Skeptical about the can at first, but sure opens up the portability of craft beer.
Light amber pour. Crisp hopped notes with a distinct citrus flavor. Dry to say the least. This is a repeater pale ale..
Can@Voldby. Pours amber with a white head. Aroma and taste is hops, citrus, some tropical fruits, malt, grape. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Nice dry bitter finish.

Served on tap at Ian's pizza. Clear light Amber color with a white head. Sweet yeast citrus aroma. Citrus pine orange bitter malt. Not as malty as expected. Medium body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rusty orange colour with thin wispy head. Aroma has some citrus peel. Flavour has caramel malt sweetness. Bitterness is moderate but builds up slowly in the aftertaste.
Can at home. Piney hoppy nose. Piney and citrus hoppy flavours. Balanced fruity bittersweet taste. Crisp and dry finish. Decent.

Can @ DØE meeting. Pours golden with white head. Aroma of malt, grassy hops, fruit, bitter citrus, orangepeel, pine. Flavor is rather bitter, malt, hoppy, grass, fruit, citrus, orange, grapefruit, pine, light resinly notes. Medium to full body, average carbonation, lasting bitter finish. Nice and hoppy, full bodied for the ABV . 211015

4 oz pour on draft at District Commons. Clear golden amber with off-white head. Aromas of biscuit, citrus, light floral. Tastes of toasty notes, biscuit, citrus, floral. Medium body with a dry finish.

Pours caramel color with off white flufdy head. Aroma is pine, grapefruit, citrus and sweet. Flavor is citrus pine up front followed by caramel and bisket flavors finishes with a bitter caramel flavor. Overall very balanced nice bitterness.
Can. Lots of citrus and pine. Also some tropical fruits and caramel. Slightly sweet and moderately bitter. Dry and bitter finish.

Can at America on Tap Saturday
I’m kind of surprised I haven’t rated this before. Rich bready caramel earthy spicy citrus and pine hops to counter, just a great beer.
deep amber color; bready malt and piney hop aroma; piney hops on a medium bodied, bready malt base; some citrus notes; bitter finish

Pours a clear golden amber, with a decent sized frothy head. The aromas are resin, pine, tropical fruits, and lightly toasted cereals. The taste is fairly sweet, with a bitter kick in the finish. The mouthfeel is medium, and so is the carbonation. Long aftertaste with resiny flavours.

can, thanks heaps baerwaldt. pale amber with a light haze and a fluffy head; loads of oranges in the aroma, cottee’s orange mandarin cordial, light pine and other citrus; plenty of bitterness, slightly oily mouthfeel, loads of pine and citrus; delicious

From a 19.2 ounce can bought at the QT. Pours an orange gold, slightly translucent and an inch of lingering head. Nice carbonation. Faint nose. Beautiful taste. Perfectly hopped. Wonderful beer, especially from a gas station.

355ml can. Light unclear orange color with white to off white head. Hoppy and malty aroma, pine, citrusy fruity, grassy, caramel. Sweet and bitter taste like aroma. Medium oily body with sot carbonation.

On tap at Malone’s in East Point, GA. Clear copper pour with a one-finger white head and lots of lacing on the glass leaving rings all the way down marking every sip. Nice biscuit and citrus aroma and taste. Medium slick mouthfeel. Very nice.
Amber colour. Thick dark cap. Spur aroma. Moderately bitter with sour and fruity notes. Bitter aftertaste.

Pours a clear copper with a lasting white head that leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is toffee, mango with a slight dustiness. Taste is caramel, citrus, slight hints of pineapple and pine with a long bitter finish that really hits the spot. A real favourite of mine and my go to IPA. This particular can isn’t the freshest (canned in March) which may explain the dusty scent/taste.
12 oz. can, part of mix six. Pours amber with foamy off white, lasting head. Aroma of hops, citrus and pine. Taste was hoppy at first, citrus and some pine. Long lingering bitter finish.

Bottle @ home. Pours a clear amber color with orange notes. Has a a large, lasting and creamy off white head and nice lacing. Well balanced hop and malt aroma with intense grapefruit, pine apple, flowery and somewhat spicy hops, caramel, biscuits, bread. Medium bodied, Medium carbonation. Taste is medium bitter, refreshingly crisp and has resinous hoppiness combined with a dry, low to medium sweet, malt backbone. Notes of caramel, toffee, biscuits, rye bread. Hop flavors of grapefruit, blood orange, flowers, pine apple. Assertive, balanced and lasting bitterness with notes of grapefruit. One of my favorite American Pale Ales.
Can from Head of Steam Newcastle. Robust pale ale, hoppy and rich on biscuity flavours.

Average American Pale Ale. Was better on nitro than I've had in the past, but nothing remarkable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pretty, hazy dark golden beer with a lasting white head. Aroma is floral (it smells a bit like women’s perfume, I got some white rose and lavender there), woody and slightly fruity (orange peel). Dry, moderately bitter and citrusy taste, decent hoppy aftertaste. Palate is surprisingly smooth without being watery, is this a nitro can? Kinda tastes like it and the ridiculous foam retention would speak for this too. Anyway, one of the best beers I’ve had from this style so far, of course nowhere near a solid IPA, for me at least, but sometimes a normal pale ale is just the right thing, and this one is remarkably well executed.
Pours a dark amber from a can. Not sure why, but this is just middle of the road for me for such a high rating. Nothing really good and nothing really bad about it.

Small Can. Piwo pakowane w puszce, ale to jest chyba wyjatkowo dobre. Najlepsze puszkowe piwo jakie testowale,. Zapach perfumowy, chmiele dajace aromat dojrzalych rozowych grejfrutow, pomaranczy i liczi. Smak tak samo egzotyczny jak aromat, wiec kilogramy wnet cytrusow, do tego morela suszona i brzoskwinia. Kolor miedziany, lekko mglisty. Pianka srednia ale bardzo trwala, puszysta. Doskonale i niemal perfekcyjne APA, gdyby nie ta puszka, a szkoda
Klar amber farve med lyst skum. Lukt av sitrus, malt og humle. Smak av sitrus, malt og humle. Vinmonopolet Kvadrat.
tap. very tasty pale ale! Definitely one of the better ones - pretty close to an IPA - maybe a RIPA even. Loved it. This brewery makes some great stuff

Slightly foggy bright orange, film of creamy head. Aroma is quite balanced really, with lots of cereal, fruity malts. Of course there are hops (grapefruit first and foremost, resin backup), but for an american ale, it’s remarkably malt-forward. Which is nice! It’s refreshing, drinkable, and has a lot going on. Pours a glowing, coppery-amber color with a great looking, big, froth head.

Smells of lemon zest and cakey malts with a whiff of kiwi added, showcasing a pleasant, thoughtful put together hop profile. 

Drinks easy, with a higher carbonation to it, revealing a fitting balance between hops and malts.

Tastes of syrup coated malts, melting together with fruity hops, revealing orange and crisp lemon zest. Lemon invites a prominent dryness to the otherwise very malty beer, giving it an inviting hop character, which then results into a long lasting, lemony dryness. During its finish, the beer reveals a mineralic quality, carried to the tongue by the lively carbonation, while malts and hops are still there, providing an easy agreeable bitterness.

Well balanced and easy drinkable, while its hop profile is well integrated into the distinct malts and the higher, refreshing carbonation.

Poured from a 12 OZ can into a pint glass.
This beer is a clear amber color with a large white head. The taste is really good and is full of malt, hops and citrus. the aroma matches the flavor and it is a medium bodied beer with heavy carbonation. Overall, this is my second favorite beer from Oskar behind Ten Fiddy.

Orange body with a thick white head. Sweet toffee smell with a taste to match. Smooth & creamy with balanced citrus & lightly fruity bitterness. A refreshing full bodied pale ale.

It has been quite some years now since I first saw canned American craft beers and I remember being a bit skeptical about them, associating cans with metallic taste and cheaply made, bland beer styles, primarily lager and strong lager for alcoholics. Now I like them a lot, with the cans being lined with polymer in between the beer and the metal eliminating the metallic flavour; the countless craft beer cans are appealing to the eye, practical in use and protect the beer from light and oxygen probably better than a glass bottle does. This Dale’s Pale Ale started the canned craft beer movement with the intention of being able to easily take good beer outdoors on a walk in the Rocky Mountains, so I am happy to be able to taste one. It has a practically clear but eventually hazy, very warm and deep amberish orange colour with vivid fizz, supporting a creamy, moussy, complexely lacing, egg-white head with good retention. Lovely dry-hopped, blossomy and fruity aroma jumps into the nose, of overripe papaja, pink grapefruit, damp pine wood, soap, chicken stock, cookies, rose petals, hint of burnt toast and roasted pine nuts, bitter honey, tulips. Crisp, refreshing onset of redcurrant, mango, pineapple and starfruit, so a touch exotic but not overly so, sweetish with sourish balance further increased by a well-attenuated carbonation; a vague salty accent announces hoppiness, but passes through a soft, very bready, even somewhat biscuity malt flavour; the hoppiness, established by the three classic C-hops Centennial, Columbus and Cascade then blossoms in the finish, resiny, spicy, citrussy, notably piney, with an explicitly drying and bittering effect, very long and very quenching. Exemplary APA, less ’agressive’ than your average modern-day American style IPA with more bready malt sweetness coming through. I would recommend this as a perfect introduction to the APA style, and the can proves its point: the beer was canned fourteen months ago and I am eager to assume it would have been too ’old’ and weak in aroma if it had been simply bottled, but in this vessel, it has kept an unexpectedly large amount of its delicate hop fragrance.  I guess canned IPAs can be stored longer than bottled IPAs then, but I have yet to gain more experience with this.  Time to experiment!

DATE TASTED: May 9, 2015... GLASSWARE: Kisatsky Tavern pint... OCCASION: settling in after celebrating Will’s First Holy Communion... APPEARANCE: a handsome two-thirds pint glass of orange amber clarity and one-third thick, pillowed snow-white mountainous head; lacings are legitimate and thick; ... AROMA: definite malty base to build around; some caramel; some grainy, earthy tones; Centennial’s light hops suggest a flower bed...PALATE: a medium-bodied, textured mouthfeel--surprisingly balanced, with ample action at the teeth and the tongue; aftertaste despite its subtle flavors; thick texture with average carbonation... TASTE: some citrus early, but much more floral aspects throughout; again, BIG uncanny balance of malt and hop... OVERALL: at long last, Dale’s Pale Ale is in the books, and rewardingly too; unlike many/most modern American pales, this one packs a malty punch that keeps the pitchiness of the hops in check--a beer worth sipping or sessioning...
